skill.name: Agent Development
skill.description: This skill should be used when the user asks to create an agent, add an agent, write a subagent, agent frontmatter, when to use description, agent examples, agent tools, agent colors, autonomous agent, or needs guidance on agent structure, system prompts, triggering conditions, or agent development best practices for Claude Code plugins.
skill.summary: Create autonomous agents for Claude Code plugins with proper structure, triggering conditions, and system prompts
skill.author: Anthropic

security_audit.summary: Evaluated 345 static findings across 7 files (2413 lines). All findings are FALSE_POSITIVES. The scanner triggered on markdown documentation patterns (code fences, security discussion text) and standard bash constructs in a validation script. This is legitimate educational documentation for Claude Code plugin development with no malicious code or security risks.

static_findings_evaluation.finding: [MEDIUM] external_commands: Ruby/shell backtick execution (227 locations across SKILL.md, examples/, references/)
static_findings_evaluation.reasoning: Scanner detected backtick characters in markdown files. These are markdown code fence delimiters for formatting example code, not actual Ruby/shell command execution. The skill is documentation explaining agent creation - no commands are executed.

static_findings_evaluation.finding: [HIGH] blocker: Weak cryptographic algorithm (110 locations across all .md files)
static_findings_evaluation.reasoning: Scanner detected algorithm names (md5, sha1, des) in documentation. These are mentioned as examples of what NOT to use in security discussions. The skill discusses security best practices and warns against weak algorithms - it does not use them.

static_findings_evaluation.finding: [HIGH] filesystem: Path traversal sequence (2 locations in examples/agent-creation-prompt.md:146, references/agent-creation-system-prompt.md:87)
static_findings_evaluation.reasoning: Scanner detected '../' sequences. These are legitimate path examples showing agent file directory structure (e.g., 'plugin-name/agents/analyzer.md'). No user input is processed - these are hardcoded documentation examples.

Scanner triggered on 'md5' substring in 'validate-agent.sh'. This is a benign validation script for agent file structure. The 'md5' reference is in echo output text describing validation checks, not cryptographic code.

Scanner detected command substitution constructs in validate-agent.sh. These are standard bash features used in a legitimate validation script. All substitutions use hardcoded strings or file content being parsed, not user input. No command injection risk exists.

Scanner detected 'sam' substring and flagged as Windows SAM database. This is a false positive - 'sam' appears in standard text processing commands (sed, awk) for parsing frontmatter fields. No Windows security database access or related functionality exists.
Scanner detected bash shebang '#!/bin/bash'. This is standard practice for shell scripts - not a security issue. The script is a validation utility for agent files.

Scanner detected system command mentions in documentation. These are part of validation script documentation and agent creation guidance. No actual reconnaissance or system information gathering occurs.
Scanner detected network-related terms in documentation. These are mentions in discussion of agent capabilities and quality standards - not actual network reconnaissance code.

content.user_title: Create autonomous agents for Claude Code
content.value_statement: This skill provides guidance on creating autonomous agents for Claude Code plugins. Agents handle complex multi-step tasks independently with proper triggering conditions, system prompts, and tool configurations.
actual_capabilities: Create agent markdown files with proper YAML frontmatter structure
Define triggering conditions using description field with example blocks
Write effective system prompts with responsibilities, process steps, and output formats
Configure agent model, color, and tool access permissions
Validate agent files using the provided validation script
Organize agents in plugin directory structure with namespacing
limitations: Agents require Claude Code plugin infrastructure to function
Does not execute code or access external systems directly
System prompts must follow Claude Code format to work correctly
Tool access is restricted to configured permissions only

use_cases.title: Build specialized agents
use_cases.description: Create domain-specific agents for code review, testing, documentation, or analysis tasks within your plugin.

use_cases.title: Design autonomous workflows
use_cases.description: Configure agents with specific behaviors, triggering conditions, and tool access for complex automation scenarios.

use_cases.title: Standardize agent patterns
use_cases.description: Establish consistent agent structures and best practices across multiple plugins and projects.

prompt_templates.title: Basic Agent Request
prompt_templates.prompt: Create an agent configuration for [YOUR DESCRIPTION]. Return the agent file content with frontmatter and system prompt.

prompt_templates.title: Analysis Agent
prompt_templates.prompt: Create a code analysis agent that specializes in [language or domain]. Include triggering conditions, responsibilities, and output format.

prompt_templates.title: Testing Agent
prompt_templates.prompt: Create a test generation agent for [project type]. Define its process steps, tool access, and quality standards.

prompt_templates.title: Custom Agent
prompt_templates.prompt: Create an agent with name: [identifier], model: [model], color: [color], tools: [list]. Write the full system prompt with responsibilities, analysis process, edge cases, and output format.

output_examples.input: Create an agent that reviews pull requests
output: âœ… Agent file structure: YAML frontmatter with name, description, model, color
âœ… Triggering conditions: Clear examples showing when to invoke the agent
âœ… System prompt: Defined role, responsibilities, process steps, and output format
âœ… Ready for validation with scripts/validate-agent.sh

best_practices: Use specific triggering conditions with 2-4 concrete examples showing different ways users request agent help
Apply the principle of least privilege when configuring agent tool access
Write system prompts in second person (You are...) with clear responsibilities, step-by-step process, and defined output format
anti_patterns: Using generic agent names like 'helper' or 'assistant' that are too vague to trigger correctly
Omitting example blocks from the description field, which prevents Claude from knowing when to invoke the agent
Granting all tools to every agent instead of restricting to minimum required permissions

faq.question: What is the difference between agents and commands?
faq.answer: Agents handle autonomous multi-step tasks. Commands handle user-initiated single actions. Use agents when work proceeds independently.

faq.question: How many examples should I include in the description?
faq.answer: Include 2-4 concrete examples showing different triggering scenarios. Each should have context, user request, and assistant response.

faq.question: What model should I use for my agent?
faq.answer: Use 'inherit' to match the parent session model. Choose sonnet, opus, or haiku only when specific capabilities are required.

faq.question: Can I restrict which tools an agent can use?
faq.answer: Yes. Add a tools array in frontmatter listing allowed tool names. Omit for full access or use ['*'] explicitly.

faq.question: How do I test if my agent triggers correctly?
faq.answer: Use the test-agent-trigger.sh script or manually try the example phrasings from your description field in conversation.

faq.question: What makes a good system prompt?
faq.answer: Write in second person, define clear responsibilities, provide step-by-step process, specify output format, and include edge case handling.
